me.longbow122.Homeroom.utils

Class GUIUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.longbow122.Homeroom.utils.GUIUtils

  • public class GUIUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility class for the core GUI work that needs to be done within Homeroom.

    • Constructor Detail

      • GUIUtils

        public GUIUtils(java.lang.String title,
                int height,
                int width,
                int locationX,
                int locationY,
                boolean defaultClose)
        New constructor to work with this class. Will return an instance of the class that can be accessed throughout the program.

        An empty constructor should be used if you want to access any other method within the program. This constructor will also open an empty JFrame which can be filled with components by using methods implemented within this class as seen fit.

        If more than one Window is to be opened, then it is recommended that a new object be instantiated.

        Parameters:
        title - The title of the JFrame to be shown when opened.
        height - The "height" of the JFrame. How much vertical space the window should take up.
        width - The "width" of the JFrame. How much horizontal space the window should take up.
        locationX - How deep to the left into the screen the JFrame should be. Relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - How deep downwards into the screen the JFrame should be. Relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        defaultClose - Should the window shut down the entire program when closed? True if yes, False if no.

    • Method Detail

      • closeFrame

        public void closeFrame()
        Basic method written to easily close down JFrames.

      • getFrame

        public java.awt.Window getFrame()
        Basic getter for the Window that all of these methods refer to.

        Is useful to have when needing to do things such as JOptionPane.createDialog(Component, String), where you do not have a parent component to actually pass through.

        Other than using it for the above use-case, the use of this getter is generally not recommended unless the window is to be closed.
        Returns:
        Window representing the JFrame that is currently open and associated with this object.

      • addButtonToFrame

        public javax.swing.JButton addButtonToFrame(java.lang.String buttonTitle,
                                            int buttonHeight,
                                            int buttonWidth,
                                            int locationX,
                                            int locationY)
        Basic method to add buttons to a frame.

        Fills the Window that is attributed with this class.

        Parameters:
        buttonTitle - Name of the button in the middle.
        buttonHeight - How "tall" the button should be.
        buttonWidth - How "wide" the button should be.
        locationX - The X-coordinate where the button is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-coordinate where the button is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        Returns:
        JButton that the user is able to interact with.

      • addLabelToFrame

        public javax.swing.JLabel addLabelToFrame(java.lang.String textField,
                                          int locationX,
                                          int locationY,
                                          int width,
                                          int height,
                                          boolean bold)
        Basic method to add a text field to a frame. This will allow me to add uneditable lines of text to my GUI.

        Fills the Window using the constructor within this class and its attributes.

        Parameters:
        textField - The text that is to be displayed within the text field
        locationX - The X-coordinate where the label is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-coordinate where the label is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        bold - Should the text displayed be emboldened?
        height - How "tall" should the text field be?
        width - How "wide" should the text field be?
        Returns:
        JLabel that the user is able to see, but cannot do anything with.

      • addLabelToFrame

        public javax.swing.JLabel addLabelToFrame(java.lang.String textField,
                                          int locationX,
                                          int locationY,
                                          int width,
                                          int height,
                                          boolean bold,
                                          int size)
        Basic method to add a text field to a frame. This will allow me to add uneditable lines of text to my GUI.

        Fills the Window using the constructor within this class and its attributes.

        Uses method overloading to allow for an optional size parameter.
        Parameters:
        textField - The text that is to be displayed within the text field
        locationX - The X-coordinate where the label is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-coordinate where the label is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        bold - Should the text displayed be emboldened?
        height - How "tall" should the text field be?
        width - How "wide" should the text field be?
        size - How "large" should the text within the field be?
        Returns:
        JLabel that the user is able to see, but cannot do anything with.

      • addTextField

        public javax.swing.JTextField addTextField(int locationX,
                                           int locationY,
                                           int width,
                                           int height,
                                           java.lang.String toolTip)
        Basic method to add a text field for one-lined input. Will come in handy when entering in student information. Is used to generate a text field intended for one-lined input of any size.

        Fills the Window as specified by the constructor for this class.

        Parameters:
        locationX - The X-coordinate where the fields is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-coordinate where the field is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        width - How "wide" the text field should be.
        height - How "tall" the text field should be.
        toolTip - The text to be displayed to the user which describes the text field to them.
        Returns:
        JTextField that can be further interacted with and used within the code. The user is able to input data here provided a listener has been written.

      • addPasswordField

                                                   int locationY,
                                                   int width,
                                                   int height)

        locationY - The Y-coordinate where the field is to be located, relative to the top-left corner the screen.
        width - How "wide" the text field should be.
        height - How "tall" the text field should be.
        Returns:
        JPasswordField that can be further interacted with and used within the code. The user is able to input data here provided a listener has been written.

        Basic method to add a drop-down menu for selection of particular options or enums.

        Fills the Window as specified by the constructor for this class.
        Parameters:
        locationX - The X-Coordinate where the menu is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-coordinate where the menu is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        width - How "wide" the text field should be.
        height - How "tall" the text field should be.
        menuChoices - String array for the particular choices within the drop-down menu.
        Returns:
        JComboBox that can be further interacted with and used within the code. The user is able to input data here provided a listener has been written.

      • addProgressBar

        public javax.swing.JProgressBar addProgressBar(int locationX,
                                               int locationY,
                                               int width,
                                               int height,
                                               int progress)
        Basic method to add a progress bar to any GUI of my choosing.

        Fills the Window as specified by the constructor for this class.
        Parameters:
        locationX - The X-Coordinate where the bar is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-Coordinate where the bar is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        width - How "wide" the bar should be.
        height - How "tall" the bar should be.
        progress - The number in % that the bar should be filled by.
        Returns:
        JProgressBar that can be further interacted with and used by the code.

      • addDatePicker

        public com.github.lgooddatepicker.components.DatePicker addDatePicker(int locationX,
                                                                      int locationY,
                                                                      int width,
                                                                      int height,
                                                                      java.lang.String text,
                                                                      java.lang.String tooltip)
        Basic method to add a "DatePicker" to any GUI.

        Fills the Window as specified by the constructor for this method.

        The DatePicker allows users to click on the button that is generated, and a calender GUI will appear which the user is then able to pick a date from.

        A DateChangeListener can then be used with this object to allow me to perform certain actions with the date and on the event this happens. The DatePicker class from the LGoodDatePicker library was used to handle most of the logic within this method.
        Parameters:
        locationX - The X-Coordinate where the date picking button is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-Coordinate where the bar is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        width - How "wide" the button should be. Doesn't seem to be working very well, but it's not too big of a problem.
        height - How "tall" the button should be. Doesn't seem to be working very well, but it's not too big of a problem.
        text - The "title" of the button. What text should the user see on the button to ensure that they know what it does upon clicking it?
        tooltip - The tool tip text within the button. What text should be shown to the user when they hover over it?
        Returns:
        DatePicker object which has been placed within a GUI and can still be further interacted with and used.

      • addTextArea

        public javax.swing.JTextArea addTextArea(int locationX,
                                         int locationY,
                                         int width,
                                         int height,
                                         java.lang.String tooltip)
        Basic method to add a multi-line, multi-column, editable (unless specified otherwise through a method) area of text input.

        Fills the Window as specified by the constructor.
        Parameters:
        locationX - The X-Coordinate where the area is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        locationY - The Y-Coordinate where the area is to be located, relative to the top-left corner of the screen.
        width - How "wide" the area should be.
        height - How "tall" the area should be.
        tooltip - The tooltip text within the area. What text should be shown to the user when they hover over this?
        Returns:
        JTextArea object which has been placed within a GUI and can still be further interacted with and used.
